title: I Disavowed "Toxic Backlinks": Here's What Happened
description: Last month, I exported all "toxic" and "potentially toxic" backlinks to three of our blog posts from a well-known SEO tool. Did traffic tank?
content: Joshua Hardwick Head of Content @ Ahrefs (or, in plain English, I'm the guy responsible for ensuring that every blog post we publish is EPIC). Get the week's best marketing content Email Subscription Subscribe Leave this field empty if you're human: Contents On July 26th 2024, I exported all ‚Äútoxic‚Äù and ‚Äúpotentially toxic‚Äù backlinks to three of our blog posts from a well-known SEO tool. There were 129 URLs in total, which I disavowed in Google Search Console.After disavowing, traffic (as reported by GSC) fell by 7.1%:Sidenote. Google began rolling out a Core Update on August 15th, which is why I cut the experiment short to only 20 days. My plan was to leave it running for a full month, but I think just shy of three weeks is enough time to see results anyway.Before disavowing, according to GSC, traffic to these posts was trending slightly upward:After disavowing? Slightly downward:However, Ahrefs‚Äô organic traffic estimates tell a slightly different story. Visibility is trending slightly downward before disavowing‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ and after disavowing:I asked Patrick Stox how he‚Äôd interpret this. Here‚Äôs what he said:I would personally look at Ahrefs data here. Average search volume in Ahrefs will show if it impacted rankings and visibility, although our data may be slower to update than GSC. GSC can have seasonality, luck, etc. involved, so it‚Äôs not as consistent of a measure.Patrick Stox, Product Advisor & technical SEO AhrefsMakes sense. In this case, it looks like disavowing had little to no impact on rankings/visibility overall. But let‚Äôs take a closer look at the data‚Ä¶ContentsTest pagesThe data above is for all three pages combined, so let‚Äôs take a look at what happened to each page individually.Page 1: 12% traffic dropThis page was our SEO pricing guide.For the 20-day period before the disavow, the post got 574 organic visits. This fell by 12% to 505 visits in the following 20 days (when the disavow was in place).Before disavowing, organic traffic to this post was flatlining:After disavowing, it‚Äôs still flatlining:Ahrefs data tells a slightly different story‚Ä¶Before disavowing, estimated organic traffic was trending slightly downward:After disavowing, it‚Äôs flatlining:Long story short? Disavowing might have had a small positive impact, but I believe it‚Äôs more likely that a long downward trend is just finally leveling off.Page 2: 8.25% traffic dropThis page was our list of top YouTube searches.For the 20-day period before the disavow, the post got 291 organic visits. This fell by 8.25% to 267 visits in the following 20 days (when the disavow was in place).Before disavowing, organic traffic to the post was trending upward:After disavowing, it‚Äôs trending downward:Ahrefs‚Äô data tells the same story‚Ä¶Before disavowing, estimated organic traffic was trending upwards:After disavowing, it‚Äôs trending downwards:The results seem pretty clear: disavowing likely had a negative impact‚Äîespecially with a big drop in estimated traffic around ten days after.Page 3: 12.82% traffic growthThis page was our list of top Bing searches.For the 20-day period before the disavow, the post got 156 organic visits. This grew by 12.82% to 176 visits in the following 20 days (when the disavow was in place).Before disavowing, organic traffic to this post was trending upward:After disavowing, it‚Äôs still trending upward:Ahrefs tells a slightly different story here‚Ä¶Before disavowing, estimated traffic was trending ever so slightly (it really is slight!) downward:After disavowing, it‚Äôs the same story:So, disavowing seemed to have little or no impact here‚Ä¶What does all of this mean?My interpretation of these results is that disavowing ‚Äútoxic backlinks‚Äù basically did nothing. It seemed to hurt one page a bit, maybe slightly help another, and have no impact on another.In short, blindly disavowing ‚Äútoxic backlinks‚Äù reported by SEO tools is unlikely to have much if any positive impact‚Äîat least according to our data.Is this a surprise? Not really. Google has been saying this pretty much forever:That said, while the most likely outcome of disavowing is basically nothing, it‚Äôs definitely still risky. Disavowing ‚Äútoxic backlinks‚Äù could tank your traffic, as this reply to John on Reddit illustrates:Does this mean that disavowing is always a bad idea? No. If you already have a manual penalty for unnatural links or a very large number of manipulative links (e.g., paid links), then you should absolutely disavow. Google recommends this‚Ä¶You should disavow backlinks only if:You have a considerable number of spammy, artificial, or low-quality links pointing to your site,ANDThe links have caused a manual action, or likely will cause a manual action, on your site.‚Ä¶ and so does Marie Haynes:There are two situations where we will recommend to our clients a thorough link audit followed by filing a disavow:The site has a manual action for unnatural links in GSC.The site has a very large number of links that we feel the webspam team would consider to be ‚Äúmanipulative‚Äù.Marie Haynes, CEO Marie Haynes ConsultingIf that‚Äôs not you, then disavowing ‚Äútoxic backlinks‚Äù‚Äîespecially those reported by SEO tools‚Äîprobably isn‚Äôt the best idea or use of your time. As Marie Haynes said, they‚Äôre unlikely to be truly toxic anyway:I find that the truly toxic links‚Ä¶the ones that could have the potential to harm your site algorithmically are rarely returned by an SEO tool.Marie Haynes, CEO Marie Haynes ConsultingThat said, plenty of SEOs don‚Äôt agree with this advice and are convinced that disavowing ‚Äútoxic backlinks‚Äù helps. If that‚Äôs you and you‚Äôre seeing good results from disavowing, fantastic! Don‚Äôt let me stop you üôÇFor everyone else, it‚Äôs probably not the best idea‚Ä¶This isn‚Äôt the first time we‚Äôve studied this either. My colleague Patrick disavowed all links to these same three posts back in 2021‚Äîand traffic fell off a cliff:We didn‚Äôt specifically disavow ‚Äútoxic‚Äù backlinks here, but links clearly still help pages rank. If an SEO tool wrongly labels some of these helpful links as ‚Äútoxic‚Äù and you disavow them, it could harm your traffic.My advice? Spend your time improving your SEO, not disavowing ‚Äútoxic backlinks‚Äù that might actually be helping you!Got questions? Disagree? Ping me on LinkedIn (or X if you insist!) I Deleted the Content From Two Posts To See if They‚Äôd Still Rank. Here‚Äôs What Happened Would Google really rank blank pages? Or will rankings drop like a stone when I delete the content? Here's the answer. How Many New Backlinks Do Top-ranking Pages Get Over Time [New Data by Ahrefs] Do top-ranking pages get links at a faster pace than lower-ranking pages? We analyzed 200,000 top-ranking web pages across 10,000 keywords to find out.

headers.text: I Disavowed ‚ÄúToxic Backlinks‚Äù: Here‚Äôs What Happened

author: Joshua Hardwick
